content.text: The total mass of the masses and the mass hanger is \(300\mathrm{g}\)
Calculate the total weight of the masses and the mass hanger
total weight =   .........  N
Determine the time in seconds for 20 oscillations from the time shown in Fig. 1.2
time for 20 oscillations =   .........  s
Calculate the time in seconds for **one** oscillation
time for one oscillation =   .........  s
A student pulls the mass hanger down and then releases it. The mass hanger and masses oscillate up and down
The student uses a stop-watch to time 20 oscillations. Fig. 1.2 shows the time reading on the stop-watch after the \(20^{\text{th}}\) oscillation
When the student pulls the mass hanger down, energy is stored in the elastic band as elastic potential energy
Describe what happens to this energy store when the student releases the mass hanger and it moves upwards
Fig. 1.1 shows some masses on a mass hanger attached to an elastic band. The elastic band is stretched by the masses
A student is doing some physical exercise. Fig. 2.1 shows the student holding a \(50 \text{N}\) weight
The pivot in the shoulder is \(0.90 \text{m}\) from the centre of mass of the weight
Calculate the moment of the weight about this pivot
moment of the weight =   .........  \(N\) m
Describe the motion of the athlete in sections AB and DE
section AB
section DE
Calculate the distance moved by the athlete from time \(=\) 0 to time \(=\) 5.0 s
The student does some running exercises. Fig. 2.2 shows the speedâ€“time graph for one exercise
Fig. 3.1 shows a metal block and its dimensions
Calculate the volume of the metal block
Calculate the density \(\rho\) of the metal using the equation
density of metal =   .........  \(g / cm^3\)
The metal block is placed in some liquid. The metal block floats on the liquid
Suggest a value for the density of the liquid
A different metal block has a mass of \(86 \text{g}\) and a volume of \(8.0 \text{cm}^3\)
A student has a measuring cylinder, a beaker of liquid and a balance
Describe how the student can use this equipment to determine the density of the liquid
Describe how electrical energy may be obtained from the gravitational potential energy of the water behind a hydroelectric dam
Apart from cost, state **two advantages** of generating electricity using a hydroelectric power station compared with using a coal-fired power station
Apart from cost, state **two disadvantages** of generating electricity using a hydroelectric power station compared with using a coal-fired power station
Coal-fired power stations provide electricity for homes and industry
A government decides to replace a coal-fired power station with a hydroelectric power station
Determine the resultant horizontal force on the trolley
resultant force =   .........  N
direction of resultant force =
The total weight of the trolley and boxes is 900 N
The area of each wheel in contact with the ground is \(8.0 \text{cm}^2\). The trolley has four wheels
Calculate the pressure on the ground due to the total weight of the trolley and boxes. Include the correct unit in your answer
pressure on the ground =   .........  unit   .........
A woman starts to push a trolley across the floor. Fig. 5.1 shows the horizontal forces acting on the trolley
Describe the motion of the gas particles
State how the motion of the gas particles changes when the gas in the container is cooled
Explain how the gas particles exert a pressure on the walls of the container
Fig. 6.1 represents gas particles in a container. The container is at room temperature
State the name for the transfer of thermal energy through a metal
A metal can contains some water. The metal can is heated as shown in Fig. 7.1
Describe how thermal energy causes the movement of water shown in Fig. 7.1
A student places equal masses of water into two metal cans. The cans are identical apart from one having a white outer surface and the other having a black outer surface
The student places the two cans in direct sunlight. The temperature of the water increases in both cans. After 10 minutes, the temperature increase is greater in one of the cans
State and explain which can has the greater increase in temperature
Draw on Fig. 8.1 to indicate the amplitude of the wave. Label the amplitude A.
Draw on Fig. 8.1 to indicate **one** wavelength of the wave. Label the wavelength L.
The graph in Fig. 8.1 represents a wave on the surface of the water
Fig. 8.2 shows the wavefronts as they approach a barrier placed at an angle of \(45^{\circ}\) to the wavefronts
On Fig. 8.2, draw **three** wavefronts after they have reflected from the barrier. Draw an arrow to show the direction of travel of these wavefronts.
The student replaces the barrier in Fig. 8.2 with a different barrier, as shown in Fig. 8.3
Fig. 8.3 shows the wavefronts as they reach the barrier
On Fig. 8.3, draw **three** wavefronts after they have passed through the narrow gap.
The student creates waves in the water tank and places various barriers in their path
A student uses a tank of water to observe waves on the surface of the water
In Fig. 9.1, one region is unlabelled
State the name of the unlabelled region
Complete the sentence
The direction of the arrow in Fig. 9.1 shows the regions of the electromagnetic spectrum
in order of increasing
Fig. 9.1 shows the regions of the electromagnetic spectrum. One region is not labelled
State two uses for X-rays
State why X-rays can be harmful to people
The student wants to determine the resistance of the light-dependent resistor (LDR)
Draw on Fig. 10.1 to show how the student connects a voltmeter into the circuit. Use the correct symbol for the voltmeter.
The current in the LDR is 0.020A when the potential difference (voltage) across the LDR is 5.4 V
Calculate the resistance of the LDR
resistance of LDR =   .........  \(\Omega\)
A student connects the circuit shown in Fig. 10.1
When the student shines a light onto the LDR, its resistance is \(150\Omega\). The resistance of the variable resistor in the circuit is \(180\Omega\)
Determine the combined resistance of the LDR and the variable resistor
combined resistance =   .........  \(\Omega\)
The primary voltage \(V_{\mathrm{p}}\) to the transformer is 240 V
The number of turns on the primary coil \(N_{\mathrm{p}}\) is 590 turns and the number of turns on the secondary coil \(N_{\mathrm{s}}\) of the transformer is 48 turns
Calculate the secondary voltage \(V_{\mathrm{s}}\) of the transformer
secondary voltage \(V_{\mathrm{s}} =\)   .........  V
The plug connecting the transformer to the supply voltage contains a fuse
Describe how a fuse works
A battery charger for a laptop computer includes a transformer
Complete Table 12.1 by writing the missing property in each of the empty boxes
State which type of radiation, alpha, beta or gamma, is the most penetrating
Table 12.1 gives some properties of three different types of radiation
An isotope of beryllium, Be, has the nuclide notation:
Fig. 12.1 shows a diagram of one atom of this isotope
Complete the labelling of Fig. 12.1. State the names for X and for Y
X
Y
